In case you missed it: The Cherokee Nation is building eight new facilities and remodeling four others in response to COVID-19. Cherokee Nation leaders broke ground Tuesday on $25 million worth of Respond, Recover and Rebuild projects that range from PPE manufacturing and space for social distancing, to food outreach sites and a new employee health care facility.

‚¨áÔ∏è Here is a quick recap on these projects! Wado!

post_text:
Cherokee Nation leaders joined community volunteers to help Cherokee elders apply for the tribe‚Äôs Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elders Assistance Initiative on Tuesday in Catoosa and on Thursday in Muskogee. Osda!!

Tribal Councilor Joe Deere helped to process applications and answer questions from Cherokee elders in Catoosa, and Tribal Councilor Mike Dobbins helped out in Muskogee.

The Cherokee Nation launched the elder assistance initiative to help Cherokee elders age 62 and older with costs related to COVID-19 relief, including food security and utility expenses.

‚ÄºÔ∏èREMINDER: The RRR Elder Assistance Application deadline is today, September 11 by 11:59 p.m. Eligibility requirements‚Ä¶

post_text:
Exciting plans for the Cherokee Heritage Center! The Cherokee National Historical Society announced today its plans to partner with Cherokee Nation on a strategic plan for the long-term success of the organization.

The plan requires new legislation that would dissolve the current Cherokee National Historical Society organization and transfer all assets to Cherokee Nation, including the iconic Cherokee Heritage Center. The legislation would also create a new Cherokee National Historical Society under the laws of the Cherokee Nation to provide continued oversight and guidance for the facility and its holdings.

Check out the full story below ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

post_text:
This past weekend, the Cherokee Nation held its virtual 68th annual Cherokee National Holiday which included several online events as well as the inaugural Drive-In Movie Nights, held at One Fire Field in Tahlequah.

The three-night, socially responsible Drive-in Movie Nights featured Cherokee Language Speakers Night, Cherokee Women in Film Night and Cherokee Premiere Night, which included the highly anticipated pilot episode of the new Cherokee-language cartoon series ‚ÄúInage‚Äôi,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIn The Woods.‚Äù

We caught up with Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. as well as others at Cherokee Premiere Night to talk about the event! Give it a watch.

Cherokee Nation Career Services is now offering an Accelerated Business Technology Course! üñ•üìùüóÉ

This eight week course is designed to provide a real-world, experiential based skill building program for students interested in entering the office clerical and administrative assistant fields.

‚úÖ Guided instruction
‚úÖ Small group activities
‚úÖ Self-paced learning through online resources

All will be combined to give students the opportunity for learning new skills, deepen their understanding of the roles and responsibilities of office and clerical staff, and increase their overall employability as future job seekers! üíºüëç

Evening classes are available at our Tahlequah location, and afternoon and evening classes are available at our Pryor location.

For more information about our Accelerated Business Technology Course, call our Career Services office today!

For Pryor, call 918-825-7988
For Tahlequah, call 918-453-5555

üì£ Check it out! Cherokee Nation Film Office is helping develop Native talent in the film and television industry by offering 50 new scholarships for certification courses with the Oklahoma Film & TV Academy. üé•

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. announced the scholarship opportunities at the inaugural Drive-In Movie Nights, hosted during the 68th annual Cherokee National Holiday.

Scholarships are offered to citizens of any federally recognized tribe with preference given to Cherokee Nation citizens interested in pursuing the Film Crew 101 certification with the Oklahoma Film & TV Academy. The self-guided online program is delivered through a series of podcasts that offer an in-depth look at the different roles on a film or TV set and what they do. It‚Äôs a great first step to getting in the film and TV industry!

‚úÖ To learn more about the Film Crew 101 certification and to apply for the CNFO scholarship, visit cherokee.film/scholarships/

‚û°Ô∏è Read more details at the link below ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

üõé In case you missed it: Cherokee Nation announced four Cherokee Nation citizens received the distinction of Cherokee National Treasure for their work in preserving and promoting Cherokee art and culture during the virtual 68th annual Cherokee National Holiday events.

David Crawler, of Tahlequah; Crosslin Smith, of Vian; Traci Rabbit, of Pryor; and Dorothy Sullivan, of Norman, were selected as this year‚Äôs recipients.

Cherokee Nation also honors tribal citizens and organizations that made significant contributions for statesmanship, patriotism, community leadership and devotion to the Cherokee Nation during the Holiday events.

Check out this video to learn about the historical significance behind this annual event and what it means to our tribal sovereignty. Osda!

Our Cherokee Ambassadors including Miss Cherokee Meekah Roy, Jr. Miss Cherokee Desiree Matthews and Little Cherokee Ambassadors would like to welcome each and every one of you to the virtual 68th annual Cherokee National Holiday!

post_text:
Cherokee Nation leaders joined community volunteers to help Cherokee elders apply for the tribe‚Äôs Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elders Assistance Initiative in Okay on Thursday and in Claremore on Friday. Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. joined Tribal Councilor Rex Jordan in helping to process applications and answer questions from Cherokee elders in Okay, and Tribal Councilors Janees Taylor and Keith Austin helped with this process in Claremore.

The Cherokee Nation launched the elder assistance initiative to help Cherokee elders age 62 and older with costs related to COVID-19 relief, including food security and utility expenses.

The RRR Elder Assistance Application deadline has been extended to September 11. The application can be completed online anytime before Sept. 11 by visiting www.cherokee.org. Look for the purple Elder Assistance Initiative graphic to begin the application.

T-shirts range from small to 3XL. Shirts ranging in size from Small to XL are $10 and 2XL and 3XL shirts are $12. Only cash and checks are accepted, no debit or credit cards.

Cherokee Nation departments wanting to purchase shirts for their staff can email jennifer-kirk@cherokee.org with the departments name, T-shirts sizes and a contact person.

post_text:
Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner and Chief of Staff Todd Enlow had a special visitor today, Cherokee Nation citizen and 2019-2020 Miss Indian NEO Madison Gardner.

Madison and her family lost her grandmother fluent Cherokee speaker Dolly Raper to COVID-19 in July. Madison met with Chief Hoskin to discuss how she could use her platform as Miss Indian NEO to advocate for masks at her college as well as bring awareness to the Cherokee language and COVID-19.

Madison, of Salina, is a sophomore at Northeastern Oklahoma A&M College in Miami, Oklahoma, and is studying to be a Physical Therapy Assistant.

We look forward to seeing great things from you, Madison! Wado!

post_text:
The Cherokee Nation has lost 13 fluent Cherokee speakers in the month of August. We take a moment to pay our respect for these beloved speakers. Cherokee Nation‚Äôs thoughts and prayers are with each of their families during this difficult time. Donadagohvi.

‚ÄúIt saddens me to lose our Cherokee speakers and I take great pride in knowing the legacy they each leave behind not only to their family and friends but to their Tribal Nation as first-language Cherokee speakers. When we lose our language, we lose our identity, and their legacy reminds us that we must absolutely do everything we can to preserve the Cherokee language for future generations. Sadly, we know that Cherokee Nation loses more than a hundred Cherokee speakers per year, and with the current global pandemic in our midst, our elders speakers and our language have been even more at risk. To their families, on the behalf of the Cherokee Nation, we are truly sorry and know, that each will be sorely missed.‚Äù ‚Äì Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr.

During the elder sign-up events, Cherokee Nation staff assist Cherokee elders ages 62 or older with completing the online Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elder Assistance Initiative application.

post_text:
August was a busy month for the Labor and Delivery doctors, nurses and staff at W.W. Hastings Hospital!

W.W. Hastings Hospital delivered 104 babies in the month of August. This is the first time the hospital has delivered this many babies in a month, in 10 years! ü§ó

Over the weekend, Dr. Tschantre Dorsett delivered the 100th baby and yesterday Ms. Athena Hair issued birth certificate #104 to the state.

W.W. Hastings is a baby-friendly certified hospital as given by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children‚Äôs Fund.

Our doctors, nurses and staff take pride in their jobs each and every day. This number is a testament to our communities choosing W.W. Hastings Hospital first for their labor and delivery care! Osda!

August 31 is #InternationalOverdoseAwarenessDay, a global event held each year. #IOAD aims to raise awareness of overdose and reduce the stigma of drug-related death and seeking treatment for Addiction. According to the CDC, Opioids are the main driver of overdose deaths.

The hard truth is that in 2019, 71,730 Americans died from drug overdoses ‚Äî an increase of about 5% percent from 2018.

Take Action: If you or a loved one take opioids for pain or for the feeling they cause, you need the non-addictive, opioid overdose nasal spray called, Narcan. It can save a life. Learn how it works today, here: https://www.thinksmartok.org/restoring-life#how-use-narcan

Set up an appointment to get free‚Ä¶

In case you missed it: The Cherokee Nation recently received a nearly $300,000 grant from the Federal Transit Administration for five new transit vehicles that will replace older vans and expand services in Tahlequah and Stilwell.

Cherokee Nation‚Äôs Department of Transportation program is one of only three tribal programs in Oklahoma and one of 36 total projects in 14 states to receive one of the FTA‚Äôs Tribal Transit Program grants. The Tribal Transit Program funds help tribes like the Cherokee Nation connect citizens to jobs, health care, school, and other necessary services.

post_text:
Today, Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., Executive Director of Government Relations Kim Teehee, and District 13 Tribal Councilor Joe Deere presented a $25K check to the Tulsa Dream Center to assist with its food security efforts in that area of Cherokee Nation.

Cherokee Nation has conducted the largest emergency food distribution effort in its history in response to COVID. Partners like the Dream Center have helped make this effort a success.

Chief Hoskin and Councilor Deere gave remarks and also participated in the Center‚Äôs weekly food drive. Osda!

Also in attendance was the president of the North Tulsa Cherokee Organization Wynetta Lawry, Congressman Kevin Hern and the family who helped start Tulsa Dream Center.

The Tulsa Dream Center is a faith based charitable organization that exists to meet the needs of people in North Tulsa. To learn more about the positive impact Tulsa Dream Center is making in North Tulsa visit https://tulsadreamcenter.org/#home-section

COVID-19 Drive-Thru screening and testing is available at all Cherokee Nation Health Centers Monday-Friday (weather permitting).

post_text: Cherokee Nation‚Äôs newest Supreme Court Justice, Shawna Baker, was sworn in tonight by Justice John Garrett at the Cherokee Nation tribal complex in Tahlequah, after being confirmed by the Council of the Cherokee Nation. Chief Hoskin nominated Baker, of Tulsa, to the Cherokee Nation Supreme Court. Justice Baker has 18 years of legal experience with degrees from John Brown University, the University of Tulsa and Columbia University. She previously has served on the Cherokee Nation Gaming Commission and is a member of the Cherokee Nation bar association

Today, Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, District 6 Tribal Councilor Daryl Legg, District 5 Tribal Councilor E.O. Smith and representatives from Cherokee Nation Career Services department attended the Sallisaw Regional Chamber monthly luncheon and accepted the chamber's ‚ÄúMember of the Month‚Äù award on behalf of the Cherokee Nation. Wado!

The Member of the Month award included a plaque and a pop-up banner which will be displayed in the Cherokee Nation Career Services Sallisaw office.

An overview of the new Sallisaw Veterans Center was given by members of the board. The veterans center is expected to bring in 266 jobs to the area with an $11.9 million personnel budget. Deputy Chief Warner also spoke on the importance of both Oklahomans and Cherokees completing their 2020 Censuses on time.

Today is #WomensEqualityDay! The day was set aside by U.S. Congress in 1971 to commemorate the passage of the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, granting women the right to vote!! üí™üó≥

This morning, Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. signed a proclamation, declaring today as Women‚Äôs Equality Day in the Cherokee Nation!

Historically, the Cherokee Nation is a matriarchal society. Cherokee women are proud and powerful and fuel our success as a tribe, and comprise over 70 percent of our government‚Äôs workforce; and are represented on our executive cabinet, Council of the Cherokee Nation and serve in many department leadership roles.

The Cherokee Nation honors and celebrates Women‚Äôs Equality Day and the 100-year anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment! Osda!

In this animated video, learn how the Cherokee syllabary has been used in different technologies throughout history and how Cherokees have adapted to using Cherokee Syllabary in everyday technology, such as in social media and smart phones. üì±üíª

This animation is spoken completely in the Cherokee language as narrated by Sequoyah. Check it out at the link below!

Cherokee Language Technology

Cherokee language is something that must preserved. In this 2015 video, hear a conversation between the late fluent Cherokee speaker Durbin Feeling and Cherokee language student Patrick Rochford, spoken completely in the Cherokee language.

The video is brought to you by Cherokee Nation Translation Department as part of an Oral History Grant Project. This project featured students from the Cherokee Nation Immersion School and the Cherokee Degree Program at Northeastern State University having conversations with elders speaking only in Cherokee.

We hope you enjoy listening to Cherokee conversations as much as we do! Wado!

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., District 11 Tribal Councilor Victoria Vazquez, District 12 Tribal Councilor Dora Patzkowski, District 15 Tribal Council Janees Taylor as well as many volunteers helped Cherokee elders apply for the tribe‚Äôs Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elders Assistance Initiative in Pryor and South Coffeyville last week.

Cherokee Nation launched the initiative to help Cherokee elders age 62 and older apply for COVID-19 relief assistance. These drive-through, sign-up events help Cherokee elders apply for the assistance who may not have access to the online application.

The RRR Elder Assistance Application deadline has been extended to September 11. The application can be completed online anytime before Sept. 11 by visiting www.cherokee.org. Look for the purple Elder Assistance Initiative graphic to begin the application.

During today‚Äôs Executive and Finance Committee meeting, the Cherokee Nation‚Äôs Fiscal Year 2021 Budget was unanimously approved.

‚ÄúI could not be prouder of the teamwork exemplified by the Cherokee Nation, Treasurer and all our employees to secure such a strong financial footing for our future, and do this during the worst public health crisis in generations. We worked tirelessly to ensure the Cherokee Nation received its portion of CARES Act COVID-19 relief funds from the Treasury so we could address helping our elders with food, keeping our employees and communities safe and offer essential help to our citizens,‚Äù Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. said. ‚ÄúThat allowed us to keep our programs‚Ä¶ More

post_text:
On Tuesday, August 25, all official Cherokee Nation social media accounts will be in the Cherokee language, either in Cherokee syllabary or in its spoken form.

This is in honor of the single largest contributor to the Cherokee language since Sequoyah, Durbin Feeling, who‚Äôs funeral service is Tuesday. The Cherokee Nation has set aside a day to pay tribute to his Cherokee language contributions and out of respect for Durbin Feeling and his family.

Mr. Feeling dedicated his life‚Äôs work to the Cherokee language, devoting his time, energy and knowledge to the continuation of our spoken and written language.

Some of Durbin‚Äôs accomplishments include authoring or co-authoring at least 12 books‚Ä¶

From Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., a quick update that our Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elder Assistance Application Deadline is now extended to September 11, and students impacted by COVID-19 and awaiting technology and clothing stipends, we are now processing payments.

"Our elder assistance programs are still available. Our Deputy Chief and our Council members encouraged us to give our elders more time to apply, so that‚Äôs what we are doing. We‚Äôre extending the deadline from August 28 to September 11. Elders living anywhere at any income level are eligible for the basic $400 in assistance. For elders living on the reservation, additional assistance is available. All of this is on one simple online application."

Check out the video for more information, and when you're ready to apply online, just visit www.cherokee.org and look for the purple Elder Assistance Initiative graphic to begin the application.

The Cherokee Nation is working to improve access to quality, affordable broadband for its citizens throughout the reservation boundaries with a new grant and with leadership advocating for Indian Country on a number of federal broadband advisory boards.

The tribe is among 23 federally recognized tribes receiving a $50,000 broadband grant to evaluate broadband expansion within their communities. The National Tribal Broadband Grant was awarded from the U.S. Department of Interior‚Äôs Indian Affairs Office of Indian Energy and Economic Development to conduct a broadband feasibility study of the most rural parts of the Cherokee Nation. Check out the story ‚¨áÔ∏è

The Northeastern State University Alumni Association Board of Directors selected the 2020 honorees for Distinguished Alumni and Outstanding Young Alumni to be honored this fall through a series of special webcasts.

This year‚Äôs honorees:

Kim Teehee, Distinguished Alumna

Eric Proctor, Outstanding Young Alumnus
Brig. Gen. Jon Harrison, Presidents‚Äô Award for Community Service

post_text:
The Cherokee Nation‚Äôs single largest contributor to the Cherokee language since that of Sequoyah ‚Äî Durbin Feeling ‚Äî has passed away at age 74. Feeling, born April 2, 1946 just east of Locust Grove, was a renowned Cherokee linguist who wrote the Cherokee dictionary and worked for the tribe since 1976, most recently in the tribe‚Äôs language translation and technology department.

Donadagohvi.

The IRS continues to look for ways to help people who were unable to provide their information in time to receive Economic Impact Payments for their children.

Individuals receiving social security, supplemental security income, Veterans Affairs Compensation and Pension (C&P), and Railroad Retirement benefits with children that did not receive the $500 economic impact payment for their dependent child, the deadline has been extended for requesting the payment.

If the individual used the non-filer tool on the IRS website after May 5th to claim the child, no further action is needed. The IRS will automatically make a payment in October.

Anyone who still plans to file 2018 or 2019 taxes should‚Ä¶

YOUR FIRST LOOK! Check out the trailer for the highly anticipated Cherokee language cartoon üå≤ üå≥"Inage'i," üå≥üå≤which will premiere at our Drive-In Movie Nights. post_text:
In case you missed it: August 14, 2020 marked one year of service for Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. and his administration. Under the leadership of Principal Chief Hoskin Jr. and Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, the largest tribal nation in the United States continues to prevail and prosper even through unprecedented times.

Hoskin and Warner took office in August 2019 with a pledge to preserve, protect and defend the Cherokee Nation Constitution, while assuring tribal citizens their administration would continue to grow and promote the culture, language, heritage and traditions of the Cherokee people.

Read more at the link below:
https://anadisgoi.com/index.php/government-stories/387-cherokee-nation-administration-marks-1-year-in-office

post_text:
Today White House Coronavirus Task Force Coordinator Dr. Deborah Birx meets with tribes, including Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. for a COVID-19 round table. Tribes, including Cherokee, Osage and Muskogee Creek Nations, asked for clearer messages from the White House on mandates, to extend the December CARES ACT spending deadline and get more flexibility with funds and for direct access to vaccines. Tribal leaders expressed concerns for placement for family members who test positive in multigenerational households and community spread concerns from fall school return. Dr. Birx told tribes community groupings without masks, such as funerals, dinners, are biggest contributors to ‚Äúsuper spreader events‚Äù that lead to COVID-19 cases.
‚ÄúThis type of engagement is positive,‚Äù Chief Hoskin told Dr. Birx.
Cherokee Nation Delegate to Congress Kim Teehee, Health Services Brian Hail and Dr. Dave Gahn, and Government Relations Adam McCreary attended for Cherokee Nation.
text:
Today White House Coronavirus Task Force Coordinator Dr. Deborah Birx meets with tribes, including Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. for a COVID-19 round table. Tribes, including Cherokee, Osage and Muskogee Creek Nations, asked for clearer messages from the White House on mandates, to extend the December CARES ACT spending deadline and get more flexibility with funds and for direct access to vaccines. Tribal leaders expressed concerns for placement for family members who test positive in multigenerational households and community spread concerns from fall school return. Dr. Birx told tribes community groupings without masks, such as funerals, dinners, are biggest contributors to ‚Äúsuper spreader events‚Äù that lead to COVID-19 cases.
‚ÄúThis type of engagement is positive,‚Äù Chief Hoskin told Dr. Birx.
Cherokee Nation Delegate to Congress Kim Teehee, Health Services Brian Hail and Dr. Dave Gahn, and Government Relations Adam McCreary attended for Cherokee Nation.

‚ÄúOne year ago today, Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner and I were sworn into‚Ä¶

post_text:
Today Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. signed an executive order to establish the "Commission for the Protection of Cherokee Nation Sovereignty" in the wake of the historic U.S. Supreme Court McGirt decision.

"We must begin taking steps to expand our marshal service, attorney general's office, detention and probation budgets, our tribal court system and other areas, while staying engaged in any congressional response to legislation that protects our tribal sovereignty, keeps this historic ruling intact and ensures criminals that commit violent acts on Cherokee Nation reservation lands do not go free," Chief Hoskin said.

The Commission will analyze resource concerns, costs, and necessary steps as the Cherokee Nation prepares to exercise expanded jurisdiction.

https://www.anadisgoi.com/index.php/government-stories/384-chief-hoskin-establishes-sovereignty-commission-in-wake-of-mcgirt-decision

"We must begin taking steps to expand our marshal service, attorney general's office, detention and probation budgets, our tribal court system and other areas, while staying engaged in any congressional response to legislation that protects our tribal sovereignty, keeps this historic ruling intact and ensures criminals that commit violent acts on Cherokee Nation reservation lands do not go free," Chief Hoskin said.

The Commission will analyze resource concerns, costs, and necessary steps as the Cherokee Nation prepares to exercise expanded jurisdiction.

post_text:
We are happy to announce the Cherokee Nation has been awarded a $50,000 Tribal Broadband Grant from the U.S. Department of Interior‚Äôs Indian Affairs Office of Indian Energy and Economic Development to study the best way to improve and extend broadband services to tribal citizens. The Cherokee Nation is one of 23 federally recognized tribes and two Navajo Nation communities to receive the grant.

With the ongoing pandemic, quality broadband is needed to ensure the safety of our Cherokee elders and families. Expanding broadband services will allow more elders to see doctors through telehealth; more students to learn virtually; and more families the ability to stay connected to their community.

We are so excited to receive this grant and look forward to looking at ways to partner with existing broadband service providers to improve access to affordable and reliable broadband throughout the Cherokee Nation!

Read more at the link below ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

post_text:
Cherokee Nation and Cherokee Nation Health Services have created a voucher program to help more Cherokee citizens purchase new eyeglasses regardless of their age, income or health diagnosis.

The Eyeglass Program is designed to help Cherokees who have been examined by a Cherokee Nation Health Services optometry provider to purchase new eyewear with a $200 voucher beginning August 17.

Eligible participants must be Cherokee Nation citizens and must get their prescription and examination from an optometrist working in a Cherokee Nation Health Services facility. To receive an eyeglass voucher, make an appointment at any Cherokee Nation Health Services optometry department.

For more information on the Eyeglass Program, visit https://health.cherokee.org/cnhs-eyeglass-program/

post_text:
Some of our biggest partners in childhood development are the local chapters of the Boys & Girls Clubs of America. We work with around 10 Boys & Girls Club groups, which play a significant role for Cherokee families, providing stable and safe environments for youth to learn, play and grow.

This year we are proud to be a partner and financially support them with a total of $195,000. These funds will benefit nearly 13,000 youth, more than half of whom are Cherokee citizens.

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. and Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner discuss this program, and several others, in this week's update. Check it out!

post_text:
Cherokee Nation remembers and honors fluent Cherokee Speaker and Hog Fry Master Woody Hair, who passed away August 6.

In this segment of OsiyoTV, Woody shared stories and his traditional cooking talent with us. He will be deeply missed. There is no Cherokee word for goodbye, instead we say donadagohvi, til we meet again.

Attention: The Cherokee Nation is extending its deadline for its Respond, Recover, Rebuild Education Initiative, to give more parents time to apply!

The deadline has been extended from Aug. 7 to now Friday, Aug. 14.

Parents who have not submitted an application for a technology or clothing stipend still have time. Cherokee Nation citizens who still need to register their child for Cherokee Nation citizenship, or have a pending application for citizenship on file, can also still apply by the new Aug. 14 deadline. Citizenship applications must be completed with supporting records in order to be considered ‚Äúpending.‚Äù

Click on Cherokee.org and go to the blue RRR Education Initiative icon to‚Ä¶

post_text: Cherokee Nation Attorney General Sara Hill joins Patti Ghezzi and Stacy Leeds today for a live discussion on the McGirt Supreme Court decision. Tune in today at noon! Link below.
shared_text:
Live McGirt Supreme Court decision discussion

Northeastern State University was live.
July 31 at 3:16 PM ¬∑

NSU will host a live virtual discussion on the implications of the McGirt Supreme Court decision Aug. 6 from 12 to 1 p.m. via livestream right here on Facebook.

This Q&A style panel will provide clarity and insight into the decision and ongoing negotiations between the tribes and the State of Oklahoma and will be led by Assistant Federal Public Defender Patti Ghezzi and Dean Emeritus of the University of Arkansas School of Law Stacy Leeds.

Faculty, staff, students and community members are encouraged to join the live event and ask questions using the livestream comment section.

This map displays COVID-19 risk levels across the Cherokee Nation. Adair County, Cherokee County, Ottawa County, Rogers County, Sequoyah County and Tulsa County are all in rapid spread zones. The second image shows COVID-19 cases by age in Oklahoma, with the age group 18-35 as the highest. Please do your part to social distance, wear a mask and take other safety measures to stop the continued spread of #COVID19 in our communities.

Confirmed cases are on the rise. Protect our elders. Protect our language. Protect each other. Wado.

For more information or to stay up to date on COVID-19 cases in the Cherokee Nation visit: https://public.tableau.com/profile/cherokee.nation#!/

post_text:
The Cherokee Nation is encouraging Cherokee citizens and the community to continue to take safety precautions as the number of positive COVID-19 cases recorded in the tribe‚Äôs health care system has increased by more than 200 percent in just 30 days. As of today, August 4, Cherokee Nation Health Services has reported 856 positive COVID-19 cases, up from 219 cases on June 27.

In this video, Cherokee Nation citizen Frankie Hargis, the Cherokee Nation Registrar and a COVID-19 survivor, talks about her experience with the virus, why wearing a mask is important, and the reality of what can happen if safety precautions are not taken seriously. During her experience, Frankie‚Äôs mother passed away in April, and her step-father passed away in May, both due to complications from COVID-19.

post_text:
From the Tulsa World:

Last week, the tribe created the Cherokee Language Department, bringing the Immersion School, the Master Apprentice Program and other efforts under one organizational umbrella. And [Howard] Paden became the executive director.

A unified department will make efforts to save the language more focused, better coordinated and quicker to adapt to changing circumstances, Paden said.
shared_text:
TULSAWORLD.COM
Michael Overall: A childhood curiosity became a full-time job. Now it could change Oklahoma's future.
text:
From the Tulsa World:

Last week, the tribe created the Cherokee Language Department, bringing the Immersion School, the Master Apprentice Program and other efforts under one organizational umbrella. And [Howard] Paden became the executive director.

A unified department will make efforts to save the language more focused, better coordinated and quicker to adapt to changing circumstances, Paden said.

Michael Overall: A childhood curiosity became a full-time job. Now it could change Oklahoma's future.

post_text:
The Cherokee Nation has lost 13 fluent Cherokee speakers in the month of July. We take a moment to pay our respect for these beloved speakers. Cherokee Nation‚Äôs thoughts and prayers are with each of their families during this difficult time.

‚ÄúIt saddens me to lose our Cherokee speakers and I take great pride in knowing the legacy they each leave behind not only to their family and friends but to their Tribal Nation as first-language Cherokee speakers. When we lose our language, we lose our identity, and their legacy reminds us that we must absolutely do everything we can to preserve the Cherokee language for future generations. Sadly, we know that Cherokee Nation loses more than a hundred Cherokee speakers per year, and with the current global pandemic in our midst, our elders speakers and our language have been even more at risk. To their families, on the behalf of the Cherokee Nation, we are truly sorry and know, that each will be sorely missed.‚Äù ‚Äì Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr.

Song: Go Rest High by the Cherokee National Youth Choir

Cherokee Nation added 95 new photos ‚Äî at Sequoyah High School (Tahlequah, Oklahoma).
August 1 at 3:14 AM ¬∑ Park Hill, OK ¬∑

Congratulations to Sequoyah High School Class of 2020!

This evening, Sequoyah High School safely celebrated graduating seniors with a virtual commencement ceremony held with only the graduates in attendance. The ceremony was also live steamed on Sequoyah Schools website for all parents, family and friends to see.

Graduating in the midst of a pandemic can be a challenging time, and we cannot be more proud of these seniors. We are excited to witness the many great things that each student will achieve throughout their life. Congrats, again!

post_text:
We recently launched Cherokee Nation‚Äôs online application for our Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elder Assistance Initiative. These programs will help ease the impact of COVID-19 on Cherokee elders age 62 and older not only here in the Cherokee Nation reservation, but around the world. But, we need everyone to apply by the August 28 deadline.

Please take a moment to listen as Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. and Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner explain the enrollment process for this program, and other important details in the video below.

Then, if you qualify, log on to www.cherokee.org and click on the purple Elder Assistance graphic in the center of the website. There you will find eligibility requirements, deadlines, and instructions. If you need assistance, please direct all requests to 918-453-5464.
text:
We recently launched Cherokee Nation‚Äôs online application for our Respond, Recover and Rebuild Elder Assistance Initiative. These programs will help ease the impact of COVID-19 on Cherokee elders age 62 and older not only here in the Cherokee Nation reservation, but around the world. But, we need everyone to apply by the August 28 deadline.

Please take a moment to listen as Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. and Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner explain the enrollment process for this program, and other important details in the video below.

Then, if you qualify, log on to www.cherokee.org and click on the purple Elder Assistance graphic in the center of the website. There you will find eligibility requirements, deadlines, and instructions. If you need assistance, please direct all requests to 918-453-5464.

Attention: The Housing Authority of the Cherokee Nation is temporarily closing its Stilwell office starting tomorrow, July 30, after an employee has tested positive for COVID-19.

The office houses five employees.
Any employee who may have been exposed is being contacted and put in touch with the Cherokee Nation Public Health Team. The Stilwell HACN office will be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized with notices posted on the doors.

‚ÄúThe Housing Authority of the Cherokee Nation takes the spread of COVID-19 and threat it poses our Cherokee elders, housing clients and staff very seriously and we want to ensure we close the office and follow all safety measures. With the rise in COVID cases in our Cherokee communities, it‚Äôs important we all take extra precaution,‚Äù Housing Authority Executive Director Gary Cooper said.

Patrons can call 918-456-5482 if they need assistance. The office will reopen on Monday.

Students at Sequoyah High School will return to school this fall under a plan that will include an all-virtual option as well as limit in-person instruction to no more than 25 percent of students in the building at any one time to protect against the spread of COVID-19.

Cherokee Immersion students will start school via distance learning at home the first nine weeks of the semester to help protect the fluent Cherokee speaker, elder teaching population.

post_text:
A Virtual Sequoyah High School Graduation ceremony is being held Friday after careful planning and consideration by Cherokee Nation Public Health, Cherokee Nation Administration and Education Services.

The virtual ceremony will be held Friday, July 31 starting at 5:30 p.m. with graduating seniors only in attendance, and live streamed on Sequoyah Schools website for all parents, family and friends to see. Photos from the event will also be posted on Sequoyah's and Cherokee Nation's Facebook pages.

‚ÄúThis moment is a milestone for our graduates and a rite of passage they should each get to celebrate as a culmination of their years of achievement and friendships, but we also know that it has to be done differently and safely given the context in which we are immersed in. COVID-19 cases have increased more than 200 percent in the month of July in the Cherokee Nation, and a virtual ceremony accomplishes both these goals for celebration with strict safety measures,‚Äù said Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr.

The Cherokee Nation is establishing a new language department that will directly oversee the tribe‚Äôs Cherokee Immersion School, a team of translators and the Cherokee Language Master Apprentice Program. The new department will focus on language preservation and perpetuation, and generating more proficient second-language Cherokee speakers.

Howard Paden has been named as the executive director of the tribe‚Äôs new language department. Wyman Kirk has also been named administrator of the Cherokee Immersion School, and Jeromie Hammer has been named as principal. All three are Cherokee Nation citizens and each have been learning the Cherokee language for at least two decades.

Details here:

With a virtual Cherokee National Holiday this year and safety measures in place to help combat against COVID-19, we are honored to announce the 2019-20 Cherokee Ambassadors (Miss Cherokee, Jr. Miss Cherokee, and Little Cherokee Ambassadors) will serve another year. We will resume the ambassador competition in 2021, and we know that each of the current ambassadors will serve with dignity and responsibility. Other Native ambassador competitions are also taking similar action in an effort to keep Native youth participants, competition volunteers and organizers safe.

We look forward to accepting applications for the 2021-2022 Cherokee ambassador competitions next year! Wado.

üêù The Cherokee Nation has installed 16 new bee pollinator homes in the tribe‚Äôs heirloom garden in Tahlequah as part of a new initiative by Cherokee Nation First Lady January Hoskin to boost the population of pollinators while improving the environment. ü¶ã

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. joined First Lady Hoskin and First Daughter Jasmine Hoskin at the heirloom garden recently to hang the new pollinator homes, which will play an important role in creating sustainable habitats for pollinators such as bees. Pollinators affect one-third of food supplies across the U.S., including the traditional Cherokee plants housed in the heirloom garden.

post_text: Due to the rising cases of COVID-19 in our community and for the safety of our Sequoyah students and families, we are announcing that the 2020 graduation ceremony scheduled for July 31 is cancelled. Read more below.
shared_text:
Sequoyah Schools
July 24 at 10:38 PM ¬∑

Due to the rising cases of COVID-19 in our community and for the safety of our Sequoyah students and families, we are announcing that the 2020 graduation ceremony scheduled for July 31 is cancelled.

We know our Sequoyah graduates are disappointed, but we have to listen to the advice of our health services experts, administration and education services, as well as CDC guidance, and believe it is not safe for a mass gathering as positive COVID cases continue to rise.

The staff at Sequoyah High School explored many options but it was determined that there was just too much unnecessary risk involved to move forward with graduation at this time.

Sequoyah Graduates may pick up their diploma from the high school office during normal business hours. Those who are not able to do so will have their diploma mailed to them.

We congratulate the Class of 2020 and wish you success on all your future endeavors. Always remember, there is no limit to what you can achieve. Wado.

post_text:
Today Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. announcing he's dedicating more than $45M from the Respond, Recover, Rebuild COVID-19 spending plan to help Cherokee Elders and those in need. Programs offered include:

For low income Cherokee elders living in Cherokee Nation, we will offer $1,200 in utility bill assistance.

For Cherokee elders 62 or over living anywhere at any income level, you can apply for a $400 stipend to assist with COVID response.

Ready to make meals can be delivered to our Cherokee elders who are missing out on senior nutrition center lunches due to COVID and social distancing.

For some residents of Cherokee Nation, in all age ranges, COVID-19 has also brought economic devastation. Chief Hoskin announcing one way to help citizens make ends meet is adding $5 million to our general emergency assistance program for our citizens who are in dire economic straits with nowhere else to turn. The portal to apply is coming soon to www.cherokee.org

post_text:
On this day in Cherokee Nation history, July 23, 1832, the Cherokee National Council met for the first time at Red Clay - the last seat of the Cherokee Nation‚Äôs government before being moved west in 1838.

The Cherokee Nation‚Äôs first capital was located at New Echota (near what is now Calhoun, Georgia), but by 1832 the State of Georgia had passed laws to displace Cherokees and prevent Cherokee leaders from meeting. The Cherokees were prohibited from holding council meetings in the State of Georgia for any reason, unless to cede away their land. Because of this, the Cherokee capital was moved from New Echota to just over the Tennessee state line in Red Clay.

From 1832 to 1837, the Cherokee‚Ä¶
text:
On this day in Cherokee Nation history, July 23, 1832, the Cherokee National Council met for the first time at Red Clay - the last seat of the Cherokee Nation‚Äôs government before being moved west in 1838.

The Cherokee Nation‚Äôs first capital was located at New Echota (near what is now Calhoun, Georgia), but by 1832 the State of Georgia had passed laws to displace Cherokees and prevent Cherokee leaders from meeting. The Cherokees were prohibited from holding council meetings in the State of Georgia for any reason, unless to cede away their land. Because of this, the Cherokee capital was moved from New Echota to just over the Tennessee state line in Red Clay.

From 1832 to 1837, the Cherokee‚Ä¶

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. and Attorney General Sara Hill address the recent agreement in principle following the U.S. Supreme Court's McGirt decision.

Chief Hoskin explains, "Cherokees have long asserted that our original homelands were exchanged for a new reservation by the U.S. government. Our tribal Constitution has long affirmed its boundaries and established our authority to govern ourselves and this land. We will continue to do so, as we always have."

It‚Äôs #NationalTattooDay! Did you know the use of tattoos run deep in historic Cherokee culture? post_text:
The Cherokee Nation takes a moment to pay its respect to the family of Robert Girty, a fluent Cherokee speaker and member of the Cherokee Speaker‚Äôs Bureau, who passed away recently.

The Cherokee Nation‚Äôs thoughts and prayers are with the Girty family.

Girty, 74, of Tahlequah, was raised in a traditional Cherokee home where Cherokee was spoken as his first language and officially signed the Cherokee Speaker‚Äôs Roll in the past year. His Cherokee name was Li‚Äôwi, and he was the general plumber for the Bell waterline project.

Robert took great pride in being a Cherokee citizen and was devoted to the preservation of the Cherokee language.

‚ÄúAs Chief, it saddens me to see more and more of our Cherokee speakers walking on from this Earth. When we lose our language, we lose our identity, and speakers such as Robert leave a tremendous void carrying our language on to the next generation. I‚Äôm deeply sorry for the family‚Äôs loss, and Mr. Girty will be sorely missed by his family, by the Cherokee speakers and by this Tribal Nation,‚Äù Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. said.

The Muscogee (Creek), Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw and Seminole Nations announced today an agreement-in-principle to formalize the positions they share with the State of Oklahoma regarding future legislation following the Supreme Court ruling in McGirt v. Oklahoma.

Leaders of the Five Tribes said the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling in McGirt makes clear their long-held position that the boundaries described in the Nations‚Äô treaties with the United States remain intact and continue to mark treaty homelands. Each of the Nations‚Äô constitutions affirm these boundaries, and each Nation has and will continue to exercise its sovereign powers within those boundaries.

‚ÄúCherokees have always fought to protect‚Ä¶

üß† #TriviaTuesday ü§îüîÆCan you name this wild plant?üåø

This plant is a potent medicine that can be extremely poisonous if not handled and prepared correctly. The roots are made into a tea, which is drunk for its laxative properties. This plants roots are comprised of several ‚Äújoints,‚Äù which are the product of new stalks rising each year. Cherokee healers are careful not to use the root joints, as they contain the plant‚Äôs poison. The portion of the root between the joints is used for medicine. It is said that if someone touches this plant, that person should not go near a garden for four days, or else the garden will be ruined.üò± Because of the short height of the plant and its umbrella-like leaves, it is also said that the Little People use these plants for cover from the rain.

This plant can be found growing throughout the Cherokee Nation among shady areas in rich, moist woodland soil. What is this plants name?üçÉüå± Comment your answer below!‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

You can find the application online at www.cherokee.org; just look for the blue Respond, Recover and Rebuild Education Initiative link on the front page. You'll also find an important FAQ at the very top of the Cherokee Nation's website to help answer some of your most frequent questions. If you still have questions, feel free to call our education initiative call center during normal business hours at (918) 453-5088.

In case you missed it: The Cherokee Nation recently contributed nearly half a million dollars total to 136 rural Oklahoma fire departments. The contributions help to support volunteer fire departments, which otherwise rely on fundraisers, membership dues and the help of good Samaritans to maintain their vital operations.

In addition to the contributions, two Volunteer Fire Departments of the Year and five Volunteer Firefighters of the Year were recognized for their service.

text:
In case you missed it: The Cherokee Nation recently contributed nearly half a million dollars total to 136 rural Oklahoma fire departments. The contributions help to support volunteer fire departments, which otherwise rely on fundraisers, membership dues and the help of good Samaritans to maintain their vital operations.

In addition to the contributions, two Volunteer Fire Departments of the Year and five Volunteer Firefighters of the Year were recognized for their service.

Check out the full story at the link below ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

ANADISGOI.COM
Cherokee Nation invests $476,000 in northeast Oklahoma rural fire departments

Just a friendly reminder that our Cherokee Nation WIC offices are open and serving families to keep them healthy and strong during COVID-19.

Start the certification process from the comfort of your home, then drive thru and have your food benefits loaded onto your card. To get started, call your local WIC clinic or call 1- 800-256-0671 ext. 5589.

If you are having problems finding infant formula or WIC foods, call 1-800-256-0671 ext. 5585

To learn more about the Cherokee Nation WIC Nutrition Program, visit https://health.cherokee.org/public-health/women-infants-children/

Here in the Cherokee Nation, we understand that some of our citizens have endured tremendous financial setbacks from COVID-19 - higher utility and food costs from sheltering in place, or even loss in wages as businesses shut down back in March, April and May.

In this video, Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. explains how the tribe will use a portion of its Respond, Recover and Rebuild funding to address housing needs of our most vulnerable citizens.

post_text:
Cherokee Nation mourns the loss of one of its fluent Cherokee speakers and elders to COVID-19. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family of Edna ‚ÄúDolly‚Äù Raper, 67, of Kenwood. Raper retired from Kenwood School, and passed on Saturday.

‚ÄúOn behalf of the Cherokee Nation, we send our thoughts and prayers to Dolly‚Äôs family during this difficult time, and grieve with them as we have lost an outstanding Cherokee citizen. My wife January, and I, want Dolly‚Äôs, children and grandchildren to know how truly sorry we are. When we lose our language, we lose our identity, and COVID-19 has been the single most threat to our language in this generation, taking from us speakers such as Dolly. Dolly‚Äôs life and her death are deeply meaningful to her family, community and our Nation. We can give her life and passing even more meaning by recommitting ourselves to language preservation and keeping each other safe by wearing masks, social distancing and listening to health experts so that we do not lose any more of our most precious resources.‚Äù - Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin, Jr.

‚ÄúOn behalf of the Cherokee Nation, we send our thoughts and prayers to Dolly‚Äôs family during this difficult time, and grieve with them as we have lost an outstanding Cherokee citizen. My wife January, and I, want Dolly‚Äôs, children and grandchildren to know how truly sorry we are. Dolly‚Äôs life and her death are deeply meaningful to her family, community and our Nation. The COVID-19 pandemic has hit schools and students hard in a lot of ways. The very nature of education, how it is safely delivered in the midst of the biggest public health crisis in generations, has changed dramatically. That‚Äôs why Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. is announcing the $40 million Respond, Recover and Rebuild Education Initiative to help students and schools stay on track as we continue to deal with COVID-19.

In this video, Chief Hoskin outlines what the initiative will do:

Cherokee Nation Health Services has contracted with Regional Brain Institute to provide the highest quality Inpatient and Outpatient stroke consultation services. We have established Hypertension and Vascular Internal Medicine Outpatient Clinics for Cherokee Nation Citizens.

Beginning Monday July 6, Regional Brain Institute specialists will be providing services at the Cherokee Nation Outpatient Health Center in Tahlequah. The leader of these Clinic services is Dr. Anna Wanahita, MD., a nationally recognized endovascular stroke neurologist.

Dr. Wanahita is the President of Regional Brain Institute with more than 21 years of experience caring for stroke patients and individuals with complex neurological issues.

Welcome Dr. Wanahita and the RBI Team!
To schedule an appointment call 539-234-2250.

post_text: Each year the Cherokee Nation honors more than 130 rural Oklahoma fire departments during our annual Volunteer Firefighter Awards Banquet. This year, due to concerns caused by COVID-19, we‚Äôve chosen to forego an in-person gathering in order to keep our first responders safe. But we're still recognizing their service and sacrifice to our community. In this video, Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. honors our northeast Oklahoma departments and announces this year's two Volunteer Fire Departments of the Year, and five Volunteer Firefighters of the Year.

post_text:
The Housing Authority of the Cherokee Nation's efforts to build efficiency-style homes for low-income and elderly Cherokees continues in Salina, Tahlequah and Hulbert . Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. explains that this new housing initiative began under former Principal Chief Bill John Baker, and is a model that can be expanded across the Cherokee Nation.

Funding for the efficiency homes in Salina, Tahlequah and Hulbert was provided through the Indian Housing Block Grant, also known as NAHASDA.

Wado!

-The Cherokee Vote Team

Today is National #HIVTestingDay. This day is about bringing awareness and encouraging others to get tested for HIV and stop HIV.

Did you know that HIV is preventable? Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis, otherwise known as PrEP, is a one-pill-a-day option that can prevent HIV. Cherokee Nation Health Services offers PrEP for all patients who are interested. For more information, text ‚ÄúCherokee PrEP‚Äù to 97779.

Let‚Äôs stop HIV together!

Today Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. delivers this update on the 68th Annual Cherokee National Holiday.

With COVID-19 cases increasing across the state and country, and public health experts predicting a spike in infections as fall begins, an event as large as our annual holiday requires careful planning. A decision on the holiday had to be made now to protect the health and safety of our citizens.

After careful consideration and in view of guidance from our public health experts, my administration has decided it best that the 68th Cherokee National Holiday scheduled for this Labor Day Weekend be a ‚ÄúVirtual Holiday‚Äù this year.

Plans are underway so that anyone, anywhere‚Ä¶

Following FDA recommendations, Cherokee Nation Health Services advises consumers not to use any hand sanitizer manufactured by Eskbiochem SA de CV in Mexico, due to the potential presence of methanol (wood alcohol), a substance that can be toxic when absorbed through the skin or ingested. FDA has identified the following products manufactured by Eskbiochem:

‚Ä¢ All-Clean Hand Sanitizer (NDC: 74589-002-01)
‚Ä¢ Esk Biochem Hand Sanitizer (NDC: 74589-007-01)
‚Ä¢ CleanCare NoGerm Advanced Hand Sanitizer 75% Alcohol (NDC: 74589-008-04)
‚Ä¢ Lavar 70 Gel Hand Sanitizer (NDC: 74589-006-01)
‚Ä¢ The Good Gel Antibacterial Gel Hand Sanitizer (NDC: 74589-010-10)
‚Ä¢ CleanCare NoGerm Advanced Hand Sanitizer 80%‚Ä¶

National HIV Testing Day is June 27. National #HIVTestingDay is a day to encourage people to get tested for HIV and know their status.

Did you know? HIV testing can be done in the privacy of your own home. To receive an at-home HIV self-test kit in the mail, text ‚ÄúCherokee Test‚Äù to 97779. Know your body, know your status!

Today, one of our 2019-2020 Little Cherokee Ambassadors, Lindzee Scott, from the 10-12 age division, offers up some words of advice and a reminder to stay safe while we continue the battle against COVID-19 in our communities. Wado, Lindzee!

post_text:
Today, we commemorate Juneteenth, a national celebration recognizing the end of slavery in the United States.
We should all have a better appreciation for Juneteenth and the freedom, and unity, it celebrates.
On June 19, 1865 enslaved African-Americans in Galveston, Texas were finally told they were free. It was a full two and a half years after President Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863.
Cherokee Nation observes Juneteenth 2020, and we know the history, and celebration of today will resonate in new and profound ways across the country.

post_text:
Cherokee Nation reported this week its largest spike in #COVID-19 cases since the pandemic began in March, and urge citizens to maintain safety precautions at home and in public.
Several states, including Oklahoma, are reporting this week their highest new positive COVID-19 cases as well.
Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. issues the following to Cherokee Nation employees, citizens and community:
‚ÄúThis serves as a reminder that COVID-19 is still very much in our Cherokee communities. As cities have reopened offices, food establishments, city parks, businesses, including here at the Cherokee Nation, we need to practice safety precautions not only at our worksites, which is mandatory, but when we leave work, in order to prevent the spread of this virus. That includes wearing masks in public, social distancing and using hand sanitizer and cleaning frequently. We all have to do our part to maintain safety, so together, we can get through this pandemic.‚Äù

Even after 85 years after his death, Will Rogers is still putting smiles on our faces.

District 14 Tribal Councilor Keith Austin of Claremore presented these Will Rogers inspired COVID-19 masks to Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. and Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, which were gifted by Executive Director of the Will Rogers Memorial Museums Tad Jones.

You can pick up your very own Will Rogers mask at the Will Rogers Memorial Museum gift shop in Claremore, or by ordering one by phone at 918-343-8115. For more information, visit https://www.willrogers.com/

Cherokee Nation tag offices in Tahlequah, Adair, Sallisaw and Jay will be closed to walk-in visitors on Wednesdays beginning June 17 to allow staff to more quickly and efficiently process a backlog of requests submitted online and by mail during the COVID-19 pandemic. You can also visit the Cherokee Nation Tag Office website for online tag renewal options, downloadable forms, and for hours of operation and estimated wait times for each tag office: https://tagoffice.cherokee.org/

Cherokee Nation tag offices in Tahlequah, Adair, Sallisaw and Jay will be closed to walk-in visitors on Wednesdays beginning June 17 to allow staff to more quickly and efficiently process a backlog of requests submitted online and by mail during the COVID-19 pandemic. We appreciate your patience as we adjust our operations in order to better assist our citizens. Tag offices in Catoosa and Collinsville will remain open on Wednesdays.

You can also visit the Cherokee Nation Tag Office website for online tag renewal options, downloadable forms, and for hours of operation and estimated wait times for each tag office: https://tagoffice.cherokee.org/

TAGOFFICE.CHEROKEE.ORG
Cherokee Nation Tag Office

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. provides an update on CARES Act funding, COVID-19 response efforts, new leadership in the tribe's Education Services and more in his latest video:

"I am pleased to announce that a portion of the CARES Act funding will be dedicated to hazard pay to employees who worked at their work sites during the pandemic and a stipend for those who worked from home. There will be more details on this in the coming weeks. But, when you see one of our employees, please take the time to thank them for their service."

See full video here:

District 9 Tribal Councilor Mike Shambaugh along with several volunteers distributed 115 food packages and 864 half gallons of cold milk in Colcord today as part of the Cherokee Nation‚Äôs ongoing COVID-19 response effort to help Cherokee families have enough food during the pandemic.

Since the emergency food program began, the tribe has distributed over 17,500 food packages to Cherokee families across the Cherokee Nation‚Äôs 14 counties.

Councilor Shambaugh will be distributing more emergency food packages this evening in Grove from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. at Grove Junior High School parking lot, located at 517 W. 10th.

Cherokee elders who need food assistance can contact the emergency elder food hotline at 918-316-1670.

post_text:
Today, Cherokee Nation met with Cherokee County District 3 Commissioner Clif Hall and Tahlequah Fire Department Captain Mark Whittmore to present a donation of $12,000 in special project funding to help purchase a unit that will produce a disinfectant solution known as Hypochlorous Acid that will be used to help fight COVID-19.

This safe but powerful disinfectant is known to kill germs in 60 seconds and is completely harmless to humans and non-toxic to the environment, which will allow it to be used in various places and surfaces including in schools and community buildings across Cherokee County and the Cherokee Nation. Osda!

June 10 at 7:00 PM ¬∑

post_text:
The Cherokee Nation is truly saddened by the loss of our tribal citizen Rodslen Brown. Rodslen was a frequent guest in the Cherokee Nation government offices staying actively involved, always smiling from the crowd at events, and truly, truly loved her tribe and connecting to the Cherokee culture. She was an advocate of civil rights, providing opportunities to young Cherokees, and expanding Cherokee Nation programs in the field of agriculture. In 2013, Rodslen was bestowed the State of the Nation Individual Community Leadership Award as the founder and president of the Project A Association. Brown was also a TERO certified artist who weaved baskets.
On behalf of the Cherokee Nation, our thoughts and prayers are with the Brown family at this time. Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. also issued this personal note on Rodslen‚Äôs passing.
https://www.facebook.com/493244217884864/posts/709258929616724/?d=n

The Cherokee Nation‚Äôs previously postponed Volunteer Income Tax Assistance Program is now accepting appointments to help eligible families who earned $56,000 or less fill out their 2019 federal and state income taxes for free.

The Cherokee Nation postponed the VITA program in effort to help slow the spread of COVID-19. Although the program is now accepting appointments, there are a number of safety precautions in place to help keep staff and client‚Äôs safe. Some of those safety measures include:

¬∑ All VITA sites are by appointment only; no walk-ins allowed
¬∑ Masks required by both VITA staff and clients
¬∑ Temperature screening for clients before entering the office

The tribe will offer its VITA services at 12 tax preparation sites until July 15. See flyer below for more details.

For more information, call Cherokee Nation Commerce Services at 918-453-5536.

Let‚Äôs kick this Tuesday off right with 2019-2020 Little Cherokee Ambassador, Lucas Asbill, teaching us how to make arrowheads using a process called flint knapping.

Flint knapping is also a process Cherokees used to make other stone tools such as knives and other edged items used for survival. Wado, Lucas for sharing our Cherokee culture!

post_text: A portion of $32 million in CARES Act funding to help with COVID-19 response and recovery, will be used to help complete the 84,000-square-foot OSU College of Osteopathic Medicine at Cherokee Nation medical school campus in Tahlequah. Our Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner toured the construction site earlier this week. The state-of-the-art medical school building is slated for completion in 2021. In total, the Cherokee Nation received $332 million in CARES Act relief funds to help buy safety equipment for reopening, upgrade IT infrastructure, repay funds the tribe spent on COVID-19 expenses, boost programs for citizens and help strengthen Cherokee communities. #Gadugi #Together

Guests visiting any of our Cherokee Nation tag offices should please review the steps below. These are important to help us prevent the spread of COVID-19 as we strive to safely reopen our government offices.

If you are visiting any Cherokee Nation tag agency, please remain in your vehicle in the parking lot and call the number below. After speaking with an operator, your name will be placed in a queue. Please wait for a phone call or text informing you that you may enter the tag office.

(If you arrive between 7:30 and 8:15 a.m., a Cherokee Nation Tax Commission employee will be on hand to take sign-ins rather than calling the number below.)

We appreciate your patience during this process.

Cherokee Nation‚Äôs COVID-19 response effort to help Cherokee families with food security continued today with the tribe‚Äôs emergency food distribution program in Delaware and Rogers Counties.

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., District 14 Tribal Councilor Keith Austin, Oklahoma Representative Rusty Cornwell and volunteers from the Chelsea Boys and Girls Club distributed over 190 emergency food boxes as well as protective face masks that were donated from the Federal Emergency Management Agency to Cherokee families in the area.

District 9 Tribal Councilor Mike Shambaugh and several volunteers at Kansas High School distributed 140 emergency food boxes to Cherokee families‚Ä¶
text:
Cherokee Nation‚Äôs COVID-19 response effort to help Cherokee families with food security continued today with the tribe‚Äôs emergency food distribution program in Delaware and Rogers Counties.

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., District 14 Tribal Councilor Keith Austin, Oklahoma Representative Rusty Cornwell and volunteers from the Chelsea Boys and Girls Club distributed over 190 emergency food boxes as well as protective face masks that were donated from the Federal Emergency Management Agency to Cherokee families in the area.

District 9 Tribal Councilor Mike Shambaugh and several volunteers at Kansas High School distributed 140 emergency food boxes to Cherokee families‚Ä¶

post_text:
This day in Cherokee Nation History, on May 28, 1830, the Indian Removal Act was signed into law by President Andrew Jackson.

The act established a process authorizing the President to remove all Native Americans living within existing state borders and move them to unsettled land west of the Mississippi. The exchange would open up southeastern lands ‚Äì that several Native American tribes called home, including the Cherokee ‚Äì to white settlers.

The U.S. Senate passed the act by a vote of 28 to 19. The House of Representatives passed the act by a vote of 101 to 97.

Eight years later, the Cherokee would be forcibly removed by the U.S. government from southeastern ancestral homelands to what is now eastern Oklahoma.

(Information courtesy of Cherokee Nation History and Preservation)
(Photo courtesy: National Archives)

The exchange would open up southeastern lands ‚Äì that several Native American tribes called home, including the Cherokee ‚Äì to white settlers.

The U.S. Senate passed the act by a vote of 28 to 19. The House of Representatives passed the act by a vote of 101 to 97.

Eight years later, the Cherokee would be forcibly removed by the U.S. government from southeastern ancestral homelands to what is now eastern Oklahoma.

(Information courtesy of Cherokee Nation History and Preservation)
(Photo courtesy: National Archives)

May is Mental Health Awareness Month. And while we are all still facing challenges related to coping with COVID-19 and the associated feeling of isolation, it is important to remember that we are not alone.

The Cherokee Nation Behavioral Health team has designated a Behavioral Health COVID-19 helpline to offer support to anyone experiencing COVID-19 related problems. Call the hotline number at 918-316-3492, Monday-Friday, 8 a.m.-5 p.m., and speak to one of our trained Behavioral Health clinicians.

#MentalHealthAwarenessMonth

Today, Sequoyah High School held a senior drive-through celebration to honor its 2020 graduating class.

In effort to help slow the spread of COVID-19, Sequoyah High School postponed its May commencement ceremony, but teachers still wanted to do something special for their seniors. Teachers, family and friends of this year‚Äôs seniors lined the road around Sequoyah High School to show support and congratulate their seniors, while still practicing social distancing.

Most seniors wore their cap and gown and decorated their vehicles to show their Sequoyah Indian pride.

Sequoyah High School has tentatively set a commencement ceremony for the class of 2020 seniors to take place at the Chota Conference Center on July 31, at 6 p.m., using social-distancing recommendations and pending guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Congratulations, Sequoyah High School class of 2020! üéâ

Cherokee Nation's emergency elder food distribution program continued today in Locust Grove, with the tribe providing 230 boxes of food to Cherokee families. Since the program began in response to COVID-19, the tribe has provided food to more than 39,000 Cherokees through the emergency food program.

Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, Chief of Staff Todd Enlow, Tribal Councilor Janees Taylor and Cherokee Nation Businesses Board Member Brent Taylor were on hand to assist tribal staff and volunteers in distributing the food supplies to families.

Cherokee elders who need food assistance can contact the emergency elder food hotline at 918-316-1670.

Cherokee Nation's emergency elder food distribution program continued today in Vinita at the Craig County Fairgrounds, with the tribe providing more than 230 boxes of food to Cherokee families. Since the program began in response to COVID-19 moving into Cherokee communities, the tribe has provided food to more than 39,000 Cherokees through this program. Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, Chief of Staff Todd Enlow and District 11 Tribal Councilor and Deputy Speaker of the Council Victoria Vazquez were on hand with assistance from the Bluejacket Cherokee Organization and volunteers to help distribute the food supplies to families.

Cherokee elders who need food assistance can contact the emergency elder food hotline at 918-316-1670.

post_text:
Today Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr. issued the following statement regarding the Cherokee Nation filing a motion to intervene in the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians v. United States Department of Interior, recently granted in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

Under federal law, the United States government is required to consult with the Cherokee Nation on federal agency actions that potentially impact cultural grounds within the Cherokee Nation‚Äôs historic treaty territory. The Cherokee Nation was never notified of the proposed trust acquisition and has intervened to assert consultation rights under federal law.

Nurses across our Cherokee Nation health system make a difference each and every day. On day 6 of National #NursesWeek, we share photos of a few of our nurses serving on the front lines as well as messages from nurses on why they chose nursing as their career.

While we know there are no words to describe how thankful we are for all our heroic nurses ‚Äì today and every day, we thank you! #NursesWeek2020 #YON2020

post_text:
The U.S. Small Business Administration reopened its Economic Inquiry Disaster Loan Program to help provide financial assistance to farmers, ranchers and other agricultural related businesses who have been hit by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Applications for the Economic Inquiry Disaster Loan Program will be accepted at a first come, first served basis and for only a limited time. The U.S. Small Business Administration is encouraging agricultural businesses impacted by COVID-19 to apply as soon as possible.

For more information or to apply for the Economic Injury Disaster Loan visit the link below‚¨áÔ∏è

The Cherokee Nation Small Business Assistance Center continues to keep small businesses updated about federal and other programs to assist businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic. For more information, email the Cherokee Nation Small Business Assistance Center at sbac@cherokee.org or call 918-453-5536.

post_text:
Today, Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, and District 9 Tribal Councilor Mike Shambaugh helped volunteers hand out food packages to Cherokee elders in Kenwood and Kansas.

385 boxes in total were handed out today. In addition to the donations at Kansas and Kenwood, food was also delivered to Rogers County as well as 15 individual deliveries.

In total, Cherokee Nation has donated nearly 13,000 boxes of food to help Cherokee families impacted by COVID-19. #InThisTogether

post_text:
Today, Cherokee Nation Principal Chief Chuck Hoskin Jr., Cherokee Nation Deputy Principal Chief Bryan Warner, District 7 Tribal Councilor Canaan Duncan and District 8 Tribal Councilor Shawn Crittenden distributed about 300 food packages to elderly and disabled Cherokees in Stilwell and surrounding areas in Adair County to help keep their cupboards stocked during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Councilor Duncan and Councilor Crittenden also distributed about 100 food packages a piece to Cherokee Speakers in their districts this week.

More food packages from Cherokee Nation will be distributed tomorrow, May 8 at the Kenwood Community Building at 10 a.m. and Kansas School gym at noon. #InThisTogether
